abstracts.cdata!:
After the mine shaft tower and outlying
            buildings were blown apart with dynamite, their concrete
            remains were crushed into small granular pieces and poured
            down the shaft to fill the void of the abandoned mine.
            Through a trap door you can see the packed debris: fifty
            years of history reduced to dust. Four-hundred-fifty people
            used to work at the Godeni mine set in the scenic hills of
            Campulung in southern Romania. Cows graze there now and the
            air is filled with the buzz of honey bees. The Romanian
            government has closed 520 of 650 mines operating in 1997 and
            physically erased or converted 120 of those sites. The
            crumbling of Romanias once huge mining sector posed an
            enormous challenge in the late 1990s as the number of mining
            employees nationwide was halved. In 1999 the government
            turned to the World Bank for assistance in creating
            alternative jobs for ex-miners. After a slow start, their
            joint efforts to transform the mining communities are
            starting to pay off.
